1_14YkpjZoU1Q897PhRG4CWyg6CL6Rn4QEVf.body:
No, you don't download "everything", you only download the required data on the Zites you visit.
And if you wish, you may download optional files too, when prompted.

But you seed (upload) all data you already have, if it's valid.
Plus, if you don't want to seed a Zite any longer, or don't want to have it on your disk anymore, you also have the option to delete it!

1_1P7ngox2iQVMeo7Tduop4SzDrHptzaSS6B.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_417_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): My favorite thing about ZeroNet (that can't be done on clearnet) is super easy site cloning and hosting. It's two clicks max for both. Want to upload some content? New site -> paste your files -> sign -> publish -> share. That simple. On the clearnet? Well first you need to go pay for hosting (because who self-hosts? If you do, you need to call up your ISP for a static IP or find another solution), then you need to go buy a domain name, both of which you need to pay yearly for. Set up the nameservers properly so they point your domain to your host. Wait however many hours that all takes. Then ftp or ssh into your server and upload your files. It's a huge pain and expensive. [...]

I host my own website on a Raspberry Pi. It's only 25â‚¬ or so, _one time_, and for domain, I first used a free Dyn-DNS-provider (No-IP), and now I somewhat switched (still re-activating the No-IP-domain :D) to a domain I bought, which costs only 0.75cents a month (or so,.. I forgot xD).
For HTTPS I use LetsEncrypt. Not everybody thinks it's good or so, but I think so.

Yes, I admit, it all was somewhat hard'ish to set up, but I mean, _why not_!? :D
It was definitely worth learning about all that stuff.

But: I do agree, that a clearnet-site is not as safe as a zite in ZeroNet, and because I pretty much have nobody who visits my site, I can't really talk about how good _or bad_ the server actually is x(.

About the thing that the user has full control of posting stuff, _maybe_,.. because I could just go into ThunderWave's code, and edit it, so that User 1 only sees messages from a selected range. Not everybody _can_ code, not everybody _wants_ to code, not everybody is concerned about his data's _security_ (hmm, the last is somewhat not the case for probably _any_ user on the ZeroNet :D), so if User 1 is just a "normal" End-User, _why_ should he check the code?!
After all, ZeroNet isn't *just* for coders/programmers/whatever (or at least, it shouldn't!), but also for the everyday end-user, who just want's to go a different way, than the clearnet.

Zites are not always up. If all users just delete it, or have no internet access, then the user wanting to access the zite won't be able to download it (xD that's kind of a stupid argument right there, but _everything can happen_ (though, this _is_ true for somewhat private website e.g. a blog)).

So all in all, I totally agree with what you wrote! xD
(PS.: I read it all x_O)

1514147301_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
Here's a link to the [ZeroDocs](http://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#plugin-mergersite).
It doesn't really explains the Merger-Plugin though.
In short, I would describe Merger zites as databases a zite can connect to, to get and store data.
So it's just as if you as the zite had one harddrive with the code for the zite, and another one with all the data.

E.g. ZeroMe stores all of it's data within different Hubs, and those add to the ZeroMe-Merger, which is used on the ZeroMe-Zite and other clones of it like [Me.Mkg20001.bit](/Me.Mkg20001.bit/). To get all hubs, you can visit [0hub.bit](/0hub.bit/).

Also, you should really check out ZeroMe as that is the main source of getting more contacts and information about ZeroNet.
If you want, you can also check out [ThunderWave](/thunderwave.bit/), if you want to chat with me quicker..

1520150897_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJV.body:
[ThunderWave](/thunderwave.bit) has group-conversations!
To open a group-room, just replace `[GROUPID]` with the wanted name for the group: `/thunderwave.bit/?GC:[GROUPID]`.
E.g. [/thunderwave.bit/?GC:Abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz](/thunderwave.bit/?GC:Abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz).
Too short ID's get added some stuff (based on the existing ID, so it will always be the same added stuff), so e.g. a group with the ID `0` is the exact same group as the one with the ID `04533867633317641N`.

All messages and their complete metadata is completely encrypted with AES, by using the group-id as key.

You can also open a group via any other conversation in ThunderWave using the bot: `/ogc [GROUPID]`, or even send a message to a group, without leaving the current conversation by using `/sg [GROUPID] [MESSAGE]` (for more information on what the bot can do, type `/help`).

1523888661_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5.body:
The data won't get deleted when it's stored in localstorage, though of course, browsers aiming at anonymity or browsers that delete site's data, aren't included in that..

You could try and add a non-seeded file in to which the data get's added, instead of using localstorage ([file-get](http://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#fileget-inner_path-required-format-timeout) and [file-write](http://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#filewrite-inner_path-content)).
Then, as a tip, you should really encrypt the data, as doing so is not that hard at all! For that, you have to choose between [ECIES](http://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#eciesencrypt-text-publickey-return_aes_key) and [AES](http://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#aesencrypt-text-key-iv)... ECIES is based on a private key to encrypt and a public key to decrypt, and AES is just a key with an IV (which you don't need to store, as far as I remember).
I'm not sure, on what I would recommend using in your case though.

Also, it seems like the logout-button doesn't work right now.

You should definitely use the filesystem-API to read and write to a file, but it's pretty much your decision, on which of the two encryption methods you want to use (or you use a completely different one) and if you want that users can see their masterseeds everywhere for comfort, which, indeed, requires that other users are able to seed the file (so definitely encrypt in this case!!)

1555954035_1gyp68xGQMYy4CBjedTvYU6xsyxPv.body: It is possible by utilizing the [PeerMessage plugin (github)](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage) developed by @gitcenter, @krixano and @thunder33345. For the best performance, I suggest you use the new python3 version of ZeroNet together with the python3 version of just-mentioned plugin, which can both be found in the `py3`-branches of the respective repositories.

@adna, You place the plugin into the plugins folder (rename it to PeerMessage). I recommend git-cloning it into that dir instead of just downloading the py3-branch, as this way, you will be able to update the plugin easily.

To start a simple chat, this here might help you if you haven't read it yet: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage/wiki/Tutorials-%E2%80%90-Simple-chat
Documentation on that `p2p.json` file can be found here: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage/wiki/p2p.json

Basically you have to place that `p2p.json` into your zite's root, which should contain a `filter` and a `cert_signers` property (the latter is not needed, if you don't want to verify the sending peers through the normal ID providers).
To implement the .5s delay, you might also want to add `"freq_limit": 0.5`.
Put in the little code that can be found in the afore mentioned Simple chat Tutorial from PeerMessages wiki, and you should be good to go.

If you want to see it in action, I have [made a _very_ simple chat](/14SZmBpbGv5u99zibmGMd6f9NHMhMbWKUF).
It does, however, not validate the user being logged in.

You might want to consider also posting this question to [KxoQA's Development Topic](/1PHBjZSAc6mHDMkySJNs3XeSXUL7eY7Q7W/?/1HfXMzGHoz36sQBw7WqLSdxwq1agwWVR27), so that this conversation/ help isn't lost in the depths of ZeroTalk (please tell me here, if you do so). :)

I've created a repo on GitLab for my sample code :)
https://gitlab.com/AnthyG/simple-peermessage-chat-demo

1556331414_12GAPJTRmNmDZKBXc1419vhTW4WpP.body:
This totally depends on what the content / content's structure is.

If it is separated into multiple categories, of which the user maybe should be able to choose, then hubs are a great thing.
If _you_ just want to distribute large files, then you can make the optional, for which you will need to implement appropriate UI. Hubs are not really needed for that.

One problem with hubs is that if you decide to change the structure, all hubs need to be updated manually by their owner (which might be you, or might be any other user). So you should consider adding a version property to them, so that you can exclude the old ones if you do change important structure. Thus, you really have to give a few thoughts to how to structure your system, before you decide to actually do the implementation.
Another problem is that you have to add hubs manually, so that they can get merged afaik. Ofc you can also add a system which handles this on it's own, either by adding a hub when a user clones the template (e.g. GitCenter), or by loading hubs when they get opened through the UI (e.g. ZeroMe).

You can ofc also combine the two options e.g. by requiring the user to clone a hub template which can contain optional files
Also these might not be the only two, tho they are the only ones I can remember right now. ðŸ˜…

1556657973_18yjuvi7DyL85Rip57MiXEcGhkgCv.body: All interactivity in ZeroNet has to be done through plain HTML5 or with JavaScript, or, a plugin for the ZN client. To add other pages to your zite, use the method that @ssdifnskdjfnsdjk described. A link tag in HTML5 in the ZeroNet environment works just as anywhere else: `TEXT`, where `URI` is to be swapped with where you want to link to. To link to another page which is written in HTML5, you can use relative (`subdir/index.html`) or absolute (`/ziteaddress/subdir/index.html`) paths. Note, that for absolute paths to work, the zite address has to be given! For a JavaScript Router library that works with ZeroNet out-of-the-box, check out @krixano's [ZeroFrame-Router on GitHub](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroFrame-Router). It also has a VueJS component that you can easily use in your VueJS project, if that is what you use (I really recommend using Vue, if you want to make a larger zite as it greatly reduces the code you have to write as compared to e.g. jQuery, and ofc for small zites like a blog it also works like a charm). If you need any help on setting up a VueJS project in ZeroNet, @krixano has also [made a template for that on GitHub](https://github.com/krixano/zite-template) (rn, I am not sure if that is actually the real repo anymore, as it rather seems to be the code for his KxoVid), and I can also give you help on other things related to Vue, if you so desire. VueJS is ofc no requirement for developing a zite, you could also use jQuery, other libraries, or none at all. Just make sure, that you never use the clearnet resources, but download them to your zite and include them locally! You may either follow a tutorial for that on nofishs Blog: [ZeroChat tutorial (new)](/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:99:ZeroChat+tutorial), or choose to use the PeerMessage plugin as I already described [in this ZeroTalk topic](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1555954035_1gyp68xGQMYy4CBjedTvYU6xsyxPv1Bzc/Zeronet+realt+time+messaging). Just make sure to not share it anywhere public, if you want to keep it only to your friends.

If you are not a dev, consider just using ZeroNets clone feature on any chat zite that has it enabled or if the zite links to a git repo, then create a new empty zite, `git clone` into it, follow further instructions if any, and you should be good to go. E.g. my PeerMessage zite has such a repo here: https://gitlab.com/AnthyG/simple-peermessage-chat-demo (my chat, ThunderWave, also has a repo, but as I am currently working on a complete re-write, I do not recommend cloning it as of now).
[ThunderWave](/thunderwave.bit/) for example also allows to join AES encrypted group chats, the only way to make them private tho is to use a very long group id (so that it can't really be guessed, and accidentally going to that group is near impossible). To do so, either use the `/ogc [GROUP-ID]` command in the lobby or directly use a URL `/thunderwave.bit/?GC:[GROUP-ID]`, where in both `[GROUP-ID]` is to be replaced with the own group id.

@zerolespero, if that is a question regarding ThunderWave's group chat, then no, I disabled auto-updating the history for group and private chats, because I was not able to properly do it at the time when I implemented it (and I tried for weeks IIRC). Notifications are not possible right now (I believe there is a background-script plugin somewhere in the works, but I can't remember right now), at least not for group or private chat, as the messages are completely encrypted (so also the metadata), which means that there is no way to do anything through the Database system as that does not provide a function to decrypt data.

You can either use the [`wrapperGetAjaxKey`-cmd](https://zeronet.io/docs/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#wrappergetajaxkey) or the [`fileGet`-cmd](https://zeronet.io/docs/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#fileget).
Both methods require you to change the code of your exported app (or at least inject / overwrite the necessary things (e.g. `fetch` or `XMLHttpRequest`) (which could also be done outside of the exported code if that does not have any polyfills)).

The [`wrapperPermissionAdd`-cmd](https://zeronet.io/docs/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/#wrapperpermissionadd) is not usable for this case as it only "allows" CORS across different zites.

Before that, I had used RessurectionRemix for a very long time (it's certainly the most customizable ROM I've seen to-date) but the latest build of that for my phone is from like 2017 :(

So yeah, consider buying a mid-range phone (mine is / was a LG L90 D405 w7 for ~160â‚¬ or so) that is rootable and has active ROM development and you'll get immense value out of a very little price.

1575913720_1DfbNohg1UZxEJXMGS4W46bSSh3Ag.body:
First get a domain through Namecoin https://zeronet.io/docs/faq/#how-can-i-register-a-bit-domain or get a free one at [Name.YO](/1NAMEz7stUPZErkV1d3yLkVWQFa4PTqDNv)
Then edit the zite' `content.json`: https://zeronet.io/docs/site_development/content_json/#domain

> [nickwa](#comment_469_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj): By wouldn't the drawback be losing the old domain name? When I have a name.yo address, I can use either or.

The domain put in the `domain` key of the `content.json` is the default domain that will show up when you visit the zite via ZeroHello. The site address (e.g. 1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D) will always be usable.

For example, I own [ThunderWave](/thunderwave.bit) which has the address [1CWkZv7fQAKxTVjZVrLZ8VHcrN6YGGcdky](/1CWkZv7fQAKxTVjZVrLZ8VHcrN6YGGcdky) and two domains: [thunderwave.bit](/thunderwave.bit) and [thunderwave.yo](/thunderwave.yo). I've set `thunderwave.bit` to be the default domain as you can see [in it's content.json](/thunderwave.bit/content.json). So when you click on `ThunderWave` in ZeroHello, you will open `thunderwave.bit`.

This imposes the risk that if you lose the power over the domain, that your zite might get redirected to a different zite instead, when being accessed through ZeroHello (if you don't change the default domain, that is).
